title: “Best by” vs “Use by”: What They Really Mean
excerpt: Date labels are confusing. Here’s how to read them to reduce waste without risking safety.
contentHtml:
Most date labels are about quality, not safety. “Best by” and “Best if used by” signal peak quality from the manufacturer. “Use by” is the last date for quality — except on infant formula where it relates to nutritional adequacy. For safety, focus on time-in-fridge guidance and temperature control rather than printed dates.

  • Keep the fridge ≤ 40°F / 4°C.
  • Follow conservative storage timelines on this site.
  • When in doubt, throw it out.

title: Is Reheating Rice Safe? Do It Right.
excerpt: Rice can harbor Bacillus cereus if handled poorly. Cool fast, store cold, and reheat hot.
contentHtml: Cooked rice should be cooled quickly in shallow containers, refrigerated promptly, and eaten within 3–4 days. Reheat to steaming hot throughout. Avoid leaving rice at room temperature for long periods.
